clinical_study.brief_title: Walking in the HIBBOT: is Gait Improved?
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of a Novel Gait Trainer, the Hibbot, on the Development of Crouch Gait in Children With Cerebral Palsy

brief_summary.textblock: The aim of the study is to assess the impact of the innovative walking aid HIBBOT on the functions, activity and participation of young children with Cerebral Palsy, in comparison with conventional walking aids.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Lower limb kinematics during walking in degrees
primary_outcome.time_frame: baseline (at intake, T0) and after the intervention period (3 months, T1)
primary_outcome.description: The gait pattern is assessed by instrumented 3D gait analysis. Joint rotation angles of the major joints of the lower limbs will be described during walking.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Muscle activation patterns during gait in microvolts
primary_outcome.time_frame: baseline (at intake, T0) and after the intervention period (3 months, T1)
primary_outcome.description: Surface electromyography signals will be recorded during gait

secondary_outcome.measure: Lower limb kinematics during walking in degrees
secondary_outcome.time_frame: at follow up (12 months after intake, T2)
secondary_outcome.description: The gait pattern is assessed by instrumented 3D gait analysis. Joint rotation angles of the major joints of the lower limbs will be described during walking.

intervention.description: Hibbot is an assistive mechanical device, lightweight and portable. The mechanism of the Hibbot manages to control all degrees of freedom (3x rotation and 3x translation) at the level of the pelvis and lower trunk. The goal is to maximize a child's own muscle activity and postural control while giving as minimal support as needed.
Standard care involves the standard physiotherapy the child would get during clinical care.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- At risk of or diagnosed with cerebral palsy, based on MRI (uCP 86 - 89 % sensitivity) or HINE (uCP 98% ) or standard motor assessment
- age 18 months - 6 years
- GMFCS level II - IV =with potential (=able to stand and walk when supported by a therapist at the level of the pelvis and lower trunk)
- Sufficient cooperation to complete the tests.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Hip dysplasia
- Fixed contractures in the lower limb
- Botox infiltration < 6 months prior to inclusion
- Surgery < 12 months prior to inclusion
- Insufficient understanding of the interventon and tests (based on mental level assessment)
- Refractary epilepsia
